data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
We may look at the three facets of SLB (protestant work ethic, perceived system permeability, and beliefs in system legitimacy) separately to see if acculturation affect any facet more strongly than the others. 

Within the survey battery, we also have measures of racial identification and perceived racial discrimination. Battery surveys include other demographic information such as age and gender. We may use these variables as exploratory measures.

sample.value:
This study will be incorporated as part of a larger survey battery in a massive testing at the start of each academic term. Each quarter typically allows us to recruit approximately 150 Asians and 150 Asian Americans. 

With 150 people per group, this would allow us to detect a cohen’s d of .32 (for 80% power, .05 alpha, and two-sided independent t-test). Our previous study found that Asians have higher status legitimizing belief than Asian Americans with cohen’s d = .57.

analyses.value: We will test for moderation by testing two multiple regression models in R, testing the effects of Asian vs. Asian American, acculturation (first model using scores from Vancouver Index of Acculturation, the other model using time spent in the U.S.), and their interaction terms on the endorsement of SLB. First, the main effect of Asian vs. Asian American on SLB will examine H1. According to H1, we expect that being Asian will predict greater SLB than being Asian American. Second, the interaction effect will examine H2. According to H2, we expect that the effect of Asian vs. Asian American on SLB will vary by level of acculturation. Specifically, at low level of acculturation, being Asian will predict greater SLB than being Asian American; however, at high level of acculturation, the effect of Asian vs. Asian American on SLB will be significantly weaker such that the extent to which Asian endorse SLB will be closer to Asian Americans.

outliers.value: Because any students enrolled in Intro to Psychology can participate in the mass testing, we will use completed data from participants who identify as Asians (not born in USA) and Asian Americans (born in USA). We may look at comparisons with White Americans as well.

dependent.value:
Dependent variable is Status Legitimizing Beliefs using the average of 12 items (higher score = more support for SLB):
(1= strongly disagree; 7= strongly agree)
--If people work hard, they almost always get what they want.
--Most people who don't get ahead should not blame the system; they really have only themselves to blame.
--In America, getting ahead doesn't always depend on hard work.
--Even if people work hard, they don’t always get ahead.
--America is an open society where all individuals can achieve higher status.
--Advancement in American society is possible for all individuals.
--Individual members of certain groups have difficulty achieving higher status.
--Individual members of certain groups are often unable to advance in American society.
--America is a just society where differences in status between groups reflect actual group differences.
--Differences in status between groups in American society are fair.
--Differences in status between groups in American society are the result of injustice.
--It is unfair that certain groups in America have poorer living conditions than other groups.

Moderator is Acculturation using two measures. One measure is the Vancouver Index of Acculturation (1=Strongly Disagree to 9=Strongly Agree)
1. I often participate in my heritage cultural traditions.	
2. I often participate in mainstream North American cultural traditions. 
3. I would be willing to marry a person from my heritage culture.	
4. I would be willing to marry a North American person.		
5. I enjoy social activities with people from the same heritage culture as myself.
6. I enjoy social activities with typical North American people.	
7. I am comfortable working with people of the same heritage culture as myself.
8. I am comfortable working with typical North American people.	
9. I enjoy entertainment (e.g., movies, music) from my heritage culture.	
10. I enjoy North American entertainment (e.g., movies, music).	
11. I often behave in ways that are typical of my heritage culture.	 
12. I often behave in ways that are 'typically North American.'	 
13. It is important for me to maintain or develop the practices of my heritage culture.
14. It is important for me to maintain or develop North American cultural practices. 
15. I believe in the values of my heritage culture.	
16. I believe in mainstream North American values.	
17. I enjoy the jokes and humor of my heritage culture.	
18. I enjoy typical North American jokes and humor.	
19. I am interested in having friends from my heritage culture.	
20. I am interested in having North American friends.	

Measure two is a single item assessing the time that participants have been living in the U.S.
(1=less than 1 year; 2=1-3 years; 3=3-5 years; 4=5-10 years; 5=more than 10 years but I was not born in the U.S.; 6=I have been living in the U.S. since birth)

conditions.value: This is a correlational study without conditions. All participants will complete the same measures.

hypothesis.value: This study has two objectives. First, this study serves as a replication of findings from our prior studies that Asian students not born in the U.S. will endorse greater status legitimizing beliefs (SLB) than Asian American students (H1). Second, this study investigates the potential mechanism underlying such differences in SLB endorsement between Asiam and Asian American students. Specifically, we hypothesize that the more acculturated Asians are to American society, the less likely they will endorse SLB (i.e., acculturation will moderate the relationship between Asians vs. Asian Americans and SLB endorsement; H2). We reason that, upon moving to the U.S., Asians are likely to believe in the American dream (i.e., anyone, regardless of where or what class they were born into, can attain their own version of success in American society where upward mobility is possible for everyone), which corresponds to some core ideas in SLB. However, as they acculturate to American society, Asians will learn that the society is not as equal and fair as they believed, thereby endorsing less SLB.

Second, the interaction effect will examine H2. According to H2, we expect that the effect of Asian vs. Asian American on SLB will vary by level of acculturation. Specifically, at low level of acculturation, being Asian will predict greater SLB than being Asian American; however, at high level of acculturation, the effect of Asian vs. Asian American on SLB will be significantly weaker such that the extent to which Asian endorse SLB will be closer to Asian Americans.

registration_responses.conditions: This is a correlational study without conditions. All participants will complete the same measures.
registration_responses.hypothesis: This study has two objectives. First, this study serves as a replication of findings from our prior studies that Asian students not born in the U.S. will endorse greater status legitimizing beliefs (SLB) than Asian American students (H1). Second, this study investigates the potential mechanism underlying such differences in SLB endorsement between Asiam and Asian American students. Specifically, we hypothesize that the more acculturated Asians are to American society, the less likely they will endorse SLB (i.e., acculturation will moderate the relationship between Asians vs. Asian Americans and SLB endorsement; H2). We reason that, upon moving to the U.S., Asians are likely to believe in the American dream (i.e., anyone, regardless of where or what class they were born into, can attain their own version of success in American society where upward mobility is possible for everyone), which corresponds to some core ideas in SLB. However, as they acculturate to American society, Asians will learn that the society is not as equal and fair as they believed, thereby endorsing less SLB.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Income inequality and dehumanization of the poor and the rich

other.value: We will include three items about the support for income redistribution, welfare policies and progressive taxes with exploratory purposes.

sample.value: Sample size will be computed by using G-power analysis for a medium-small effect size (r = .2), 80% Power, α = .05. A minimum of 191 participants are required.

analyses.value: Bivariate correlations, regressión analysis and comparison among the variables.

dependent.value:
Main variables:

Income inequality perception: Two measures will be used. A general item asking how people perceived socioeconomic differences in their society from 1 (completely equal) to 7 (completely unequal), and a 12 items measure about the perception of economic inequality in everyday life (García-Castro et al., 2018). 


Dehumanization measures: Participants will rate the extend they think that in their society the poor and the rich are perceived as being more or less evolved (the “Ascent of Man” measure developed by Kteily et al. (2015). Responses will be from 0 (“Least evolved”) to 100 (“Most evolved”). As in the original procedure, we will include some fillers groups.

Covariates:

Socioeconomic status of the participants: Participants will report their subjective status (the 10-step MacArthur ladder, adapted from Adler et al., 2000).

Support for Economic Inequality Scale (Wiwad et al.; 2019). We will include the five items of this scale. Answer were provided from 1 (Completely disagree) to 7 (Completely agree).

Demographic details (e.g., gender, age) will be also measured.

conditions.value: None, this is a correlational study.

hypothesis.value:
We are interested in analyze if the perceived income inequality in our daily basic is associated with the humanity ascribed to the poor and the rich.

We expected that higher perceived income inequality will be negatively related to the humanity ascribed to the poor and positively related to the humanity ascribed to the rich.

q3.value:
This project investigates how people think about the temporal relation between two time intervals. There are logical systems such as Allen's Interval Calculus that break down the relations into a set of mutually exclusive categories. The subset of relations we focus on in the current experiment are: 

STARTS - 2 events starting simultaneously and ending asynchronously
FINISHES - 2 events starting asynchronously and ending simultaneously
DURING - 2 events starting asynchronously and ending asynchronously
EQUALS - 2 events starting simultaneously and ending simultaneously

The initial analysis of generated descriptions from an earlier experiment (DT1) suggest that descriptions rarely are complete and unambiguous. By contrasting the acceptability of incomplete descriptions for intervals matching the above relations, the experiment is designed to show whether there is a bias in preferences for descriptions relations by either start times only or end times only, by the underlying temporal relation, and whether these factors interact. 

The current experiment builds on a previous experiment (DT2) by expanding the 2 alternative forced choice task to a 3 alternative forced choice task in which participants have a 'neither' option.

q4.value:
Replicating the pattern from the DT2 results:
1. There will be a bias toward choosing the description relating start times when the underlying Allen relation is During, Equals, or Finishes.
2. There will be a bias toward choosing the description relating end times when the underlying Allen relation is Starts.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The experimental task is a 3 alternative forced choice between 2 partial descriptions and 'neither' for 16 problems, 4 of each temporal relation type.  An example problem (given in the instructions) is: 

Suppose the following is true: 
-The installation started at 12pm and ended at 11pm on Friday. 
-The download started at 9am and ended at 11pm on Friday. 
Which of the following is a better description? 
-The download started before the installation started. 
-The installation ended when the download ended.
-Neither description is better than the other.

The temporal information is presented initially then the question and possible responses appear after a 2 second delay. The response options are presented on buttons that the participant clicks to indicate their response. The order of descriptions (started first or ended first) is randomized by problem. Both descriptions are always logically accurate. The neither option is always presented third. The experiment ends with two debriefing questions: one asking how the participant approached deciding between the descriptions and one open ended.

q9.value: A set of  32 events, 24 unique labels with 8 randomly selected repeats, were randomly assigned to the 16 problems with the restriction of not having any two labels paired together in a problem more than once. The times were randomly generated to fit the requirements for each allen relation (during, equals, starts, finishes) and the hours were restricted to between 1am to 11pm. The day of the week was randomly assigned by problem. Finally, the display order of the problems was randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The data will be collected through Amazon Mechanical Turk by a separate research firm, Knexus Research Corporation. They will handle payment and recruitment. Eligibility for the study includes native English speakers in the US who are above 18 years of age. The study will last approximately 10 minutes, and participants will be paid $1.50 for their participation.

q14.value: The key results in DT2 were significant with a p-value well below 0.01 with 50 participants and because this is a replication with a 3rd option, 50 participants should suffice.

question.value: The underlying Allen relation of each problem scenario.

Preference between: (1) a description of the relation between the two event start times, (2) a description of the relation between the two event end times, (3) a statement that neither description is better.

Our analysis will consist of testing the effect of relation (equals, starts, finishes, during) on preference.  We will compare averages by participant for each dummy-coded response option to chance (0.33) with Wilcoxon tests.  We will also compare the averages by participant for the dummy-coded start and end responses to determine whether there is an overall bias between the two descriptions.  Then, using the start response as the dependent variable, we will conduct a non-parametric within-subject Friedman test of the relation factor, with posthoc pair-wise comparisons; an omnibus ANOVA with appropriate post-hoc contrasts; and a linear mixed effect regression model with estimated marginal means for the post-hoc contrasts.  The regression model will have the fixed effect of relation as well random factors for participant (intercept and random slopes by relation).

q20.value: The 3-alternatives (start, end, neither) will be dummy coded.

q21.value: The alpha level is set at p < 0.05 with a Šidák-Holm correction for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded for nonsensical debriefing responses (often indicating a bot instead of a human participant), for indicating they did not take the experiment seriously, for not following instructions, or for response patterns such as always selecting the first response.

q23.value: We will only include participants who completed all 16 problems.  We do record incomplete sessions that could be looked at in an exploratory manner.

q24.value:
We intend to explore random factors in the linear mixed effects regression model including age, sex, formal logic instruction, language, relation-word ('before', 'when'), and item pair (e.g. download/reconfiguration).  We will also explore if the randomly generated time intervals affected how participants responded, e.g., if participants were more likely to choose statements about time points that were closer in time for problems in the 'during' condition. Finally, we will also look at whether the presentation order or chronological order of the events affects response selection, e.g. perhaps participants prefer 'when' statements that mimic the presentation order over those that reverse it.

We will also explore using the end-response dummy-code and the neither-response dummy code as the dependent variable in the Fieldman test, ANOVA, and linear mixed effects regression.

q1.value: Regulatory Control and Defensive Reactions to Bias Feedback

q2.value: Joseph A Vitriol, Brian O'Shea, Jimmy Calanchini

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the relationship between cognitive responses that underpin performance on the Race IAT (e.g., QUAD parameters) and defensive reactions to feedback about implicit racial bias.

q4.value:
Are defensive reactions to implicit bias feedback following the completion of the Race IAT associated with holding biased associations (AC parameter) or Overcoming Bias (OB parameter)? We predict more defensiveness will be associated with lower OB and AC scores. 
Are defensive reactions to implicit bias feedback following the completion of the Race IAT associated with other cognitive processes?  The method we use here also estimates the contributions of accuracy orientation (Detection) and response biases (Guessing). However, we did not observe relationships between defensive reactions and either of these processes in the exploratory analyses, so we do not expect these relationships to emerge in confirmatory analyses.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Data collected on the Project Implicit website for the 2013 Black-White IAT (Xu, Nosek, & Greenwald, 2014) is available via Open Science Framework. However, to perform Quad modeling, the Raw data of individual's errors are required. We have prepared the datasets for both exploratory and confirmatory analysis, but have not conducted analyses on the latter at the date and time of this pre-registration. 

This dataset includes 358,896 participants.

q9.value: A subset of participants in the dataset (described above) will be randomly selected from the pool of participants who meet our inclusion criterion (described below). Two separate random draws-- one for exploratory and the other for confirmatory-- will be undertaken.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
Data collected on the Project Implicit website for the 2013 Black-White IAT (Xu, Nosek, & Greenwald, 2014) is available via Open Science Framework. However, to perform Quad modeling, the Raw data of individual's errors are required. We have prepared the datasets for both exploratory and confirmatory analysis, but have not conducted analyses on the latter at the date and time of this pre-registration. 

This dataset includes 358,896 participants.

question.value:
A subsample of 4000 White U.S. Citizens was randomly selected from the existing dataset for exploratory analyses, in which we observed that participants high (vs. low) in defensive reaction showed lower levels of both Overcoming Bias and Activated Associations. Based on those findings, this is a pre-registration for subsequent confirmatory analyses.

We intend to randomly select an additional subsample of 4000 White U.S. Citizen from the same dataset. Our goal is to replicate the observations from the exploratory analysis in this second, confirmatory sample. If, however, we fail to replicate the observations in our confirmatory test, we will repeat this procedure twice—on two independent samples of White U.S. Citizens, randomly selected from the same datasets, in the same way. We will then present the result of a meta-analysis across all four samples—the first exploratory sample, and the 3 confirmatory samples.

Our sample is constrained to participants (1) who were 18 or over, (2) who responded to all the explicit questions, including the demographic questions, (3) who received pro-White/anti-Black feedback (i.e., “Your data suggest a slight/moderate/strong implicit preference for White People compared to Black People”), which was based on their IAT score (D > .15) (4) who did not have reaction times of less than 300 ms on more than 10% of IAT trials and (5) who had fewer than 30% of errors in the IAT (Greenwald, Nosek, & Banaji, 2003). The sample was selected to ensure an even split of those with low and high defensiveness scores (see below).

q13.value: A subsample of 4000 White U.S. Citizens will be randomly selected from the existing dataset for each confirmatory analysis. That is one additional sample if we replicate our exploratory analysis, or 3 total samples if our first confirmatory analysis produces results different from or inconsistent with our exploratory analysis.

question.value:
Implicit attitudes. The Race IAT consists of two critical blocks: in one block the labels ‘European Americans’ and ‘Good’ share the same response key, and ‘African Americans’ and ‘Bad’ share another response key (the congruent block for White participants). A trial involves a stimulus appearing at the center of the screen, which corresponds to one of the four labels, and the correct response key must be made before moving onto the next trial. In the other critical block, the instruction is reversed and the labels “European Americans” and “Bad” share the same response key and “African Americans” and “Good” share the same response key (incongruent block for White participants). If participants have faster reaction times in the congruent block relative to the incongruent block, this will indicate a pro-White/anti-Black. The magnitude of this difference is reflected in a participant’s D-algorithm score (see Greenwald, Nosek, & Banaji, 2003, for further details).
Defensiveness.  Consistent with other research (Howell, Gaither, & Ratliff, 2015), we used a 3-item index of defensiveness which included the items: ‘‘Whether I like my IAT score or not, it captures something important about me’’ (reverse coded), ‘‘The IAT reflects something about my automatic thoughts and feelings concerning this topic’’ (reverse coded), and ‘‘The IAT does not reflect anything about my thoughts or feelings, unconscious or otherwise’’. A four-point Likert scale was used and coded such that: -2 = Strongly Disagree, -1 = Disagree, 1 = Agree, and 2 = Strongly Agree.

QUAD Parameters. We used the multiTree (Moshagen, 2010) software package to estimate the contributions of four cognitive processes reflected in the Quad model: Activation of evaluative information (AC), Detection of correct responses (D), Overcoming Bias (OB), and Guessing (G). The unit of analysis for Quad modeling is frequencies of correct versus incorrect responses on the IAT. A chi-square test is used to determine the model fit of the combined samples. Higher scores on the AC parameters indicate more bias, while higher scores on the D parameter indicate increased accuracy in responding during the IAT. For the G parameter, a score of .50 would indicate no guessing while scores above .50 indicate a bias in pressing the ‘Good’ key, while below .50 shows a ‘Bad’ keypress response bias. Lastly, higher scores on the OB parameter indicates a stronger ability to inhibit AC when it would conflict with a correct response (i.e., on incompatible trials).

We will conduct a median split on the defensiveness measure to create two groups—low and high defensiveness. We will present the results of each of the four parameters for the two defensiveness groups using chi-squared tests

registration_responses.q1: Regulatory Control and Defensive Reactions to Bias Feedback
registration_responses.q2: Joseph A Vitriol, Brian O'Shea, Jimmy Calanchini
registration_responses.q3: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the relationship between cognitive responses that underpin performance on the Race IAT (e.g., QUAD parameters) and defensive reactions to feedback about implicit racial bias.
registration_responses.q4:
Are defensive reactions to implicit bias feedback following the completion of the Race IAT associated with holding biased associations (AC parameter) or Overcoming Bias (OB parameter)? We predict more defensiveness will be associated with lower OB and AC scores. 
Are defensive reactions to implicit bias feedback following the completion of the Race IAT associated with other cognitive processes?  The method we use here also estimates the contributions of accuracy orientation (Detection) and response biases (Guessing). However, we did not observe relationships between defensive reactions and either of these processes in the exploratory analyses, so we do not expect these relationships to emerge in confirmatory analyses.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: A subset of participants in the dataset (described above) will be randomly selected from the pool of participants who meet our inclusion criterion (described below). Two separate random draws-- one for exploratory and the other for confirmatory-- will be undertaken.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
Data collected on the Project Implicit website for the 2013 Black-White IAT (Xu, Nosek, & Greenwald, 2014) is available via Open Science Framework. However, to perform Quad modeling, the Raw data of individual's errors are required. We have prepared the datasets for both exploratory and confirmatory analysis, but have not conducted analyses on the latter at the date and time of this pre-registration. 

This dataset includes 358,896 participants.
registration_responses.q13: A subsample of 4000 White U.S. Citizens will be randomly selected from the existing dataset for each confirmatory analysis. That is one additional sample if we replicate our exploratory analysis, or 3 total samples if our first confirmatory analysis produces results different from or inconsistent with our exploratory analysis.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Data collected on the Project Implicit website for the 2013 Black-White IAT (Xu, Nosek, & Greenwald, 2014) is available via Open Science Framework. However, to perform Quad modeling, the Raw data of individual's errors are required. We have prepared the datasets for both exploratory and confirmatory analysis, but have not conducted analyses on the latter at the date and time of this pre-registration. 

This dataset includes 358,896 participants.
registration_responses.q12.question:
A subsample of 4000 White U.S. Citizens was randomly selected from the existing dataset for exploratory analyses, in which we observed that participants high (vs. low) in defensive reaction showed lower levels of both Overcoming Bias and Activated Associations. Based on those findings, this is a pre-registration for subsequent confirmatory analyses.

We intend to randomly select an additional subsample of 4000 White U.S. Citizen from the same dataset. Our goal is to replicate the observations from the exploratory analysis in this second, confirmatory sample. If, however, we fail to replicate the observations in our confirmatory test, we will repeat this procedure twice—on two independent samples of White U.S. Citizens, randomly selected from the same datasets, in the same way. We will then present the result of a meta-analysis across all four samples—the first exploratory sample, and the 3 confirmatory samples.

Our sample is constrained to participants (1) who were 18 or over, (2) who responded to all the explicit questions, including the demographic questions, (3) who received pro-White/anti-Black feedback (i.e., “Your data suggest a slight/moderate/strong implicit preference for White People compared to Black People”), which was based on their IAT score (D > .15) (4) who did not have reaction times of less than 300 ms on more than 10% of IAT trials and (5) who had fewer than 30% of errors in the IAT (Greenwald, Nosek, & Banaji, 2003). The sample was selected to ensure an even split of those with low and high defensiveness scores (see below).

attributes.title: Projekt02McGurkM04HS19
attributes.description: This project is part of the master module M4 (HS19) of the Swiss Distance University Institute. The goal of this project is to implement the experiment "McGurk Effect: Variability and stability." by Mallick, D. B. et al. (2015) as an online experiment.

attributes.title: Code from: Quantile Graphs for EEG-Based Diagnosis of Alzheimer's Disease
attributes.description:
The Quantile Graph (QG) method converts a time series into a complex network. A detailed description of this method can be found in [1,2].
[1] Campanharo ASLO, Sirer MI, Malmgren RD, Ramos FM, Amaral LAN. Duality between Time Series and Networks. PLoS ONE. 2011.
[2] Campanharo ASLO, Ramos FM. Hurst exponent estimation of self-affine time series using quantile graphs. Physica A. 2016.

q3.value:
Prior work linking test selection to hypothesis generation has focused on single test selection in binary choice tasks (Thomas, Dougherty, & Lange, 2010).   Most testing behavior, however, occurs in environments wherein multiple tests are exploited and data is accumulated over time.  To date, no study has systematically manipulated the hypothesis set cued by information available at the beginning of the hypothesis evaluation process for the purpose of investigating sequential testing behavior.  The purpose of this experiment is to investigate test preference as it relates to cued hypothesis sets and changes to beliefs over time.  

Information utility models often invoke hypotheses when computing test value (Manktelow & Over, 1990; Over & Evans, 1994; 1996; Oaksford & Chater, 1996); however, such metrics are not suited for sequential data acquisition to evaluate more than a single hypothesis.  Probability gain, for example, conceptualizes the utility of a test as its capacity to make a hypothesis more probable.  Not only does this definition of utility lose clarity in decision environments with greater uncertainty (e.g., more than one hypothesis is considered), it presupposes that the goal of testing is to confirm a specific hypothesis or that decision-makers are aware of the correct state of the world ahead of testing.  

Alternatively, the HyGene architecture assumes that preference for information manifests as a byproduct of belief.  The need to seek diagnostic information manifests when more than one hypothesis is considered as a possible account for a dataset (Thomas, Dougherty & Lange, 2010).  Otherwise, pseudo-diagnostic or positive search is an adequate strategy for informing a decision-maker.  HyGene, however, makes more nuanced predictions regarding information preference as it relates to the set of contending hypotheses.  Provided that more than one hypothesis is considered by a decision-maker, preference should reflect the contents of working memory such that information depositories with a history of differentiating between contending states of the world are exploited at a higher rate.  

The purpose of this experiment is to test this prediction by measuring test preference in response to cues intended to bias participants towards maintaining differential belief distributions.  The statistical structure of the experimental environment is designed to exact control over the hypotheses most strongly considered by participants.  The general hypothesis was that presenting cue would predict test preference where patterns of testing behavior would appear markedly different depending on which presenting cue was presented.

q4.value: We predict that testing preferences will be influenced by the presenting cue shown to participants at the onset of a trial. The information available in the task is designed such that presentation of presenting cue #1 results in a strong belief (strong prior) in disease hypothesis #1 and a moderate belief in disease hypothesis #2. That change in belief increases the diagnostic value of test #1. The same relationship exists for presenting cue #2, hypotheses #s 2 and 3, and test #2. The pattern persists for presenting cue #s 3 and 4. Thus, the predicted pattern of results is test #1 will be preferred in response to presenting cue #1, test #2 will be preferred in response to presenting cue #2, test #3 will be preferred in response to presenting cue #3, and test #4 will be preferred in response to presenting cue #4.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study has a within-subject, repeated measures design. Participants will be exposed to numerous trials where the presenting cue and test outcomes will vary. The attached figures illustrate the statistical structure of the presenting cue/test outcome environment.

q9.value: All participants experience the same manipulations.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Undergraduate students enrolled at the Georgia Institute of Technology will be recruited to participate in this study via an online experiment management system (SONA Systems).  All participants will receive partial course credit for their involvement in the study. Incomplete data from a participant will be excluded from analysis.

q13.value: We plan to run a minimum of 60 individuals and a maximum of 80.

q14.value: We are anticipating a moderate effect size and are targeting a minimum sample of 60 individuals.

q15.value: We have control over the procedures and will terminate the study when we have reached our goal for sample size.

question.value: We have manipulated the statistical structure of the task environment, as seen in the attached figures. We will specifically use presenting cue as an independent variable in our analyses.

We will be recording the accuracy of their responses (diagnosing of patients), the total number of tests selected in a trial, the identity of the selected tests, and the order in which tests are selected.

Binomial regression analyses will be used to evaluate the accuracy of responses. We will evaluate whether blocks of trials relate to an improvement (higher) accuracy over the course of the learning phase of the experiment. Binomial regress will also be used to evaluate test selection as it relates to the presenting cue. Multinomial logistic regression analyses will be used to evaluate the order of test selection as it relates to presenting cue.

q20.value: The order a test is selected will be reversed, such that tests selected first receive a score of 4 to reflect high priority. A test selected second will be scored a 3, and so on. Unselected tests will be scored 0.

q21.value: We will be using a p-value of 0.05 to draw statistical inferences.

q22.value: Incomplete sets of participant data will be excluded from analysis. We will not exclude outliers.

q23.value: Incomplete participant data will be excluded from analyses.

Prior work linking test selection to hypothesis generation has focused on single test selection in binary choice tasks (Thomas, Dougherty, & Lange, 2010).   Most testing behavior, however, occurs in environments wherein multiple tests are exploited and data is accumulated over time.  To date, no study has systematically manipulated the hypothesis set cued by information available at the beginning of the hypothesis evaluation process for the purpose of investigating sequential testing behavior. Information utility models often invoke hypotheses when computing test value (Manktelow & Over, 1990; Over & Evans, 1994; 1996; Oaksford & Chater, 1996); however, such metrics are not suited for sequential data acquisition to evaluate more than a single hypothesis. Not only does this definition of utility lose clarity in decision environments with greater uncertainty (e.g., more than one hypothesis is considered), it presupposes that the goal of testing is to confirm a specific hypothesis or that decision-makers are aware of the correct state of the world ahead of testing.  

Alternatively, the HyGene architecture assumes that preference for information manifests as a byproduct of belief. attributes.title: Research trends in hospice and palliative medicine: a scoping review
attributes.description: As research in the field of Hospice and Palliative Medicine has grown, there has been a call for an increase in quantitative research. This novel scoping review assesses the details of how research in palliative medicine has changed over the last 15 years in the three major US palliative care journals. We describe and analyze characteristics of palliative researchers, ones that have been evaluated previously as well as additional characteristics not previously reported. Additionally, we describe characteristics of published palliative studies including the type of study, to map the current state of research in palliative medicine.

q1.value: Research trends in hospice and palliative medicine: a scoping review

q3.value: As research in the field of Hospice and Palliative Medicine has grown, there has been a call for an increase in quantitative research. This novel scoping review assesses the details of how research in palliative medicine has changed over the last 15 years in the three major US palliative care journals. We describe and analyze characteristics of palliative researchers, ones that have been evaluated previously as well as additional characteristics not previously reported. Additionally, we describe characteristics of published palliative studies including the type of study, to map the current state of research in palliative medicine.

q4.value: We hypothesize that there is an increase in total publications in hospice and palliative medicine and that a greater percent of papers will be qualitative than quantitative. We also hypothesize that a great percent of publications will be by women researchers in hospice and palliative medicine over time but the percentage of papers written by women will not be greater than by men.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: The data will be manually collected by researchers by searching each issue of 3 major palliative journals published over the last 15 years. No human subjects are included in this study. The data will be collected over 6 months. Only studies published in English will be included.

1.	Researcher characteristics - gender,  professional degree, researcher role, fellowship training
2.	Publication characteristics - name of journal, qualitative vs quantitative, type of paper
We will use Chi-squared analyses to compare between and within groups.
